We fix Î”2=50subscriptÎ”250\Delta_{2}=50 and vary Î”1subscriptÎ”1\Delta_{1} from 111 to 350035003500 to understand the impact of the ratio of dynamic range Î”1/Î”2subscriptÎ”1subscriptÎ”2\Delta_{1}/\Delta_{2} on the quantization budgets. It can be seen in Fig. 3 and Table 1 that by using proposed MAC aware scheme, the PS allocates more rate towards the user whose gradients are more informative (higher dynamic range). For instance, when Î”1/Î”2=1subscriptÎ”1subscriptÎ”21\Delta_{1}/\Delta_{2}=1, gradients from both users are equally informative, and both users are assigned equal quantization budgets k1=k2=10subscriptð‘˜1subscriptð‘˜210k_{1}=k_{2}=10. On one extreme, when Î”1/Î”2â‰¤0.16subscriptÎ”1subscriptÎ”20.16\Delta_{1}/\Delta_{2}\leq 0.16, gradients from user 222 are considered more useful than user 111, the optimal allocation is k1=4subscriptð‘˜14k_{1}=4, k2=21subscriptð‘˜221k_{2}=21. On the other extreme, if Î”1/Î”2â‰¥69.28subscriptÎ”1subscriptÎ”269.28\Delta_{1}/\Delta_{2}\geq 69.28, gradients from user 111 are more informative, hence we see that k1=50subscriptð‘˜150k_{1}=50, and k2=2subscriptð‘˜22k_{2}=2.

S4.T2.caption: Table 2: Comparison of test accuracy after T=1000ð‘‡1000T=1000 iterations.
references: In Fig. 4, we let P1=0.95â€‹PÂ¯subscriptð‘ƒ10.95Â¯ð‘ƒP_{1}=0.95\bar{P} and P2=0.05â€‹PÂ¯subscriptð‘ƒ20.05Â¯ð‘ƒP_{2}=0.05\bar{P}, and compare the proposed MAC aware gradient quantization scheme with the following schemes: a)a) uniform rate allocation subject to MAC capacity constraints, b)b) a recently proposed digital scheme in [11], c)c) SignSGD, which uses 111 bit quantization per dimension for each user [2], and d)d) TernGrad [3], which uses three levels {âˆ’1,0,+1}101\{-1,0,+1\} to quantize each dimension of the gradient. We also plot the non-quantized full resolution scheme as a baseline. In the digital scheme proposed in [11], all but the highest qtsubscriptð‘žð‘¡q_{t} and lowest qtsubscriptð‘žð‘¡q_{t} gradient values are set to zero. The remaining gradient values are then split into two groups depending on their signs. The mean of elements in each group is computed, denoted by Î±avg+superscriptsubscriptð›¼avg\alpha_{\text{avg}}^{+} and Î±avgâˆ’superscriptsubscriptð›¼avg\alpha_{\text{avg}}^{-}. If Î±avg+>|Î±avgâˆ’|superscriptsubscriptð›¼avgsuperscriptsubscriptð›¼avg\alpha_{\text{avg}}^{+}>|\alpha_{\text{avg}}^{-}| (Î±avg+<|Î±avgâˆ’|superscriptsubscriptð›¼avgsuperscriptsubscriptð›¼avg\alpha_{\text{avg}}^{+}<|\alpha_{\text{avg}}^{-}|), all remaining positive (negative) values will be set to Î±avg+superscriptsubscriptð›¼avg\alpha_{\text{avg}}^{+} (Î±avgâˆ’superscriptsubscriptð›¼avg\alpha_{\text{avg}}^{-}). Each user then transmits the location of qtsubscriptð‘žð‘¡q_{t} non-zero values and a scalar (using cð‘c bits) to describe the average value at each iteration. Therefore, the communication cost is log2â¡(dqt)+csubscript2binomialð‘‘subscriptð‘žð‘¡ð‘\log_{2}\binom{d}{q_{t}}+c. This scheme [11] is fundamentally different than the one proposed in this paper, and, moreover, the quantization budget qtsubscriptð‘žð‘¡q_{t} is the same for all users. As shown in Fig. 4, the proposed MAC aware multi-level scheme outperforms the uniform multilevel scheme, the scheme in [11], SignSGD and TernGrad. This is due to the fact that logâ¡(dqt)binomialð‘‘subscriptð‘žð‘¡\log\binom{d}{q_{t}} grows exponentially as qtsubscriptð‘žð‘¡q_{t} increases. In addition, the rates are limited by the user with the worst channel. Therefore, as it reaches the capacity of the user with the worst channel, qtsubscriptð‘žð‘¡q_{t} is still small compared to dð‘‘d. Other schemes such as SignSGD and TernGrad suffer from underutilization of channel resources, as they use a fixed quantization budget (111 bit, and 222 bits respectively per gradient dimension). We also show the testing accuracy of each scheme at the end of 100010001000 iterations (see Table 2). They are consistent with Fig. 4 where our proposed scheme is the closest to full resolution.

S4.T3.caption: Table 3: Test accuracy for proposed scheme as a function of total power.
references: For Fig. 5, we set s=1.5â€‹dð‘ 1.5ð‘‘s=1.5d, P1=0.8â€‹PÂ¯subscriptð‘ƒ10.8Â¯ð‘ƒP_{1}=0.8\bar{P} and P2=0.2â€‹PÂ¯subscriptð‘ƒ20.2Â¯ð‘ƒP_{2}=0.2\bar{P}, and vary PÂ¯Â¯ð‘ƒ\bar{P} to see the impact of increasing power, and thus, a larger capacity region. It can be seen in Fig. 5 that the performance improves monotonically with the increase in total power. The testing accuracy at the end of T=1000ð‘‡1000T=1000 iterations is shown in Table 3 as a function of the total power.
